NickSifniotis.DatabaseManager

Class DBManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • NickSifniotis.DatabaseManager.DBManager

  • public class DBManager
extends java.lang.Object

    A simple class that provides a clean, easy interface to the SQLite library.

    Instances of this class are associated with a physical database file. Applications that use multiple databases will need to maintain multiple instances of DBManager.

    Since:
    31/08/2015

    • Constructor Detail

      • DBManager

        public DBManager()

        Constructor that connects to the default database location.

      • DBManager

        public DBManager(java.lang.String database_path,
                 java.lang.String database_name)

        Constructor that creates an instance connecting to a user-specified database.

        If the path to the database does not exist, the constructor will attempt to create it.

        Parameters:
        database_path - The path where the database file is found.
        database_name - The name of the database file.

    • Method Detail

      • __set_db_location

        private void __set_db_location(java.lang.String new_path,
                               java.lang.String new_name)

        Sets the location and name of the database file.

        If the path does not exist, this method will attempt to create it.

        Parameters:
        new_path - The path where the database file will be located, without the trailing '/'.
        new_name - The name of the database file.

      • Execute

        public void Execute(java.lang.String query)
             throws java.sql.SQLException

        Executes an SQL query on the database.

        The SQL query is passed to this method through the parameter query. This method executes the query blindly; no safety or validity checks are performed at all. It would be a good idea to write external code to verify the correctness of the query before invoking this method.

        Parameters:
        query - The SQL query to execute
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - This class handles no exceptions. If the query you pass to this method is dodgy, you wear the consequences.

      • InsertAndReturnKey

        public int InsertAndReturnKey(java.lang.String query)
                       throws java.sql.SQLException

        Inserts a row into the database and returns the primary key of the newly created row.

        No checks are performed on the SQL query that is passed into this method. You could conceivably throw in a SELECT or a DELETE instead. This method is not guaranteed to behave correctly if any query other than an INSERT is executed.

        Parameters:
        query - The SQL [INSERT] query to execute.
        Returns:
        The primary key of the newly created row.
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - This class does not handle faulty queries.

      • ExecuteQuery

        public static java.sql.ResultSet ExecuteQuery(java.lang.String query,
                                              java.sql.Connection connection)
                                       throws java.sql.SQLException

        Executes an SQL SELECT query and returns the results in a ResultSet.

        Parameters:
        query - The SELECT query to execute.
        connection - The object that represents a connection to the database. It is returned by DBManager.Connect()
        Returns:
        The results of the query, stored in a java.sql.ResultSet object.
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - This class does not handle exceptions at all. Don't feed this method INSERTs or DELETEs please.

      • Connect

        public java.sql.Connection Connect()
                            throws java.sql.SQLException

        Get a connection object from the database that can be used to process SQL and so forth.

        Returns:
        A connection object that is connected to the database. Remember to close when finished!
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - Exceptions aren't handled by this class.

      • Disconnect

        public static void Disconnect(java.sql.Connection connection)

        Disconnects connection from the database.

        Parameters:
        connection - The connection to disconnect.

      • Disconnect

        public static void Disconnect(java.sql.ResultSet results)

        Disconnects results from the database.

        Parameters:
        results - The ResultSet to disconnect.

      • closeQuietly

        private static void closeQuietly(java.sql.ResultSet result)

        Quietly closes an instance of a ResultSet. The Statement and Connection that are associated with the ResultSet are also closed.

        Parameters:
        result - The instance to close.

      • closeQuietly

        private static void closeQuietly(java.sql.Connection connection)

        Quietly closes a Connection instance.

        Parameters:
        connection - The instance to close.

      • closeQuietly

        private static void closeQuietly(java.sql.Statement statement)

        Quietly closes a Statement instance, including its associated Connection.

        Parameters:
        statement - The instance to close.
